title: 111_s3858
content: The "H-2A Improvement Act" allows nonimmigrant status for dairy workers, sheepherders, and goat herders coming temporarily to the United States for agricultural labor. Special rules are established for aliens employed in these roles. Section 218 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include special rules for aliens employed as dairy workers, sheepherders, or goat herders under nonimmigrant status for an initial period of 3 years. Under section 218 of the Immigration and Nationality Act, aliens can be employed as dairy workers, sheepherders, or goat herders under nonimmigrant status for an initial 3-year period, which can be extended for an additional 3 years. Employers hiring H-2A workers for these positions are exempt from proving they are temporary or seasonal. Under section 218 of the Immigration and Nationality Act, aliens can be employed as dairy workers, sheepherders, or goat herders under nonimmigrant status for an initial 3-year period, which can be extended for an additional 3 years. Workers in these positions are not required to show that the jobs are seasonal or temporary. Eligible aliens with H-2A worker status based on employment as a dairy worker, sheepherder, or goat herder can apply for adjustment to lawful permanent resident status after maintaining such status in the US for at least 33 of the previous 36 months. Under section 218 of the Immigration and Nationality Act, eligible aliens employed as dairy workers, sheepherders, or goat herders can apply for adjustment to lawful permanent resident status after maintaining such status in the US for at least 33 of the previous 36 months. A petition for classification under section 203(b)(3)(A)(iii) can be filed by the alien's employer or the eligible alien. Under section 218 of the Immigration and Nationality Act, eligible aliens employed as dairy workers, sheepherders, or goat herders can apply for adjustment to lawful permanent resident status after maintaining such status in the US for at least 33 of the previous 36 months. No labor certification is required for an immigrant visa under section 203(b)(3)(A)(iii) for an eligible alien. The filing of a petition or application for adjustment of status is necessary. The provision described in subparagraph (B) or an application for adjustment of status based on a petition described in subparagraph (B) cannot be used as a reason to deny various requests related to H-2A workers, such as petitions for employment, extensions of nonimmigrant status, admissions, visa requests, or modifications. The Secretary of Homeland Security must extend the stay of an eligible alien with pending or approved petitions related to H-2A workers in 1-year increments until a final decision is made. The Secretary of Homeland Security must extend the stay of an eligible alien with pending or approved petitions in 1-year increments until a final determination is made on the alien's eligibility for adjustment of status. Nothing in this provision can prevent an eligible alien from seeking adjustment of status through other legal means. In subsection (j)(1), the term is redefined to exclude certain provisions of law.
